headline: Amazon Is Now America’s Biggest Company. Its 17-Year Journey to Surpass Walmart.
summary: For nearly two decades,  Walmart  has been the country’s largest company by revenue, a status it touted to prospective hires, employees and suppliers.  On Thursday, Walmart lost its crown.  Amazon.com  —a 31-year-old company—surpassed 63-year-old Walmart as the country’s largest company by annual revenue.

content.summary: For nearly two decades,  Walmart  has been the country’s largest company by revenue, a status it touted to prospective hires, employees and suppliers.  On Thursday, Walmart lost its crown.  Amazon.com  —a 31-year-old company—surpassed 63-year-old Walmart as the country’s largest company by annual revenue.

headline: Nvidia close to investing $30 billion in OpenAI's mega funding round, source says
summary: Nvidia is close to finalizing a $30 billion investment in OpenAI, as ‌the chipmaker moves to take a stake in one of ‌its largest customers, a person familiar with the matter said.  The investment is part ​of a fundraising round in which OpenAI is seeking more than $100 billion, the person said.  SoftBank Group and Amazon ⁠are also likely to participate in the round, Reuters previously reported.

SoftBank Group and Amazon ⁠are also likely to participate in the round, Reuters previously reported.

headline: Amazon's cloud unit hit was hit by least two outages involving AI tools in December, FT says
summary: Amazon's cloud unit suffered at least two outages in December stemming from ‌errors involving its own AI tools, the ‌Financial Times reported on Friday, citing people familiar with the ​matter.  In mid-December, Amazon Web Services experienced a 13-hour interruption to a system used by customers when engineers allowed its Kiro AI coding tool to carry out ‌certain changes, the ⁠report said.  An Amazon Web Services spokesperson told Reuters ​in an ​emailed response that the ​disruption was brief and ‌attributed it to user error.

headline: Amazon Overtakes Walmart as Biggest U.S. Company
summary: On Thursday, Walmart lost its crown.  Amazon surpassed the 63-year-old retailer as the U.S.'s largest company by annual revenue.  Walmart had $713.2 billion in sales in the year through Jan. 31, compared with Amazon’s $716.9 billion for its most recent full year.

content.title: Amazon Overtakes Walmart as Biggest U.S. Company
content.summary: On Thursday, Walmart lost its crown.  Amazon surpassed the 63-year-old retailer as the U.S.'s largest company by annual revenue.  Walmart had $713.2 billion in sales in the year through Jan. 31, compared with Amazon’s $716.9 billion for its most recent full year.

headline: Nvidia close to investing $30 billion in OpenAI's funding round: source
summary:
STORY: Nvidia is reportedly close to finalizing a $30 billion investment in OpenAI.

As the chipmaker moves to take a stake in one of its largest customers.

That's according to a source speaking to Reuters.

They said the investment is part of a fundraising round in which OpenAI is seeking more than $100 billion.

It would value the ChatGPT maker at about $830 billion and amount to one of the largest private capital raises on record.

Reuters previously reported that SoftBank Group and Amazon are also likely to take part in the round.

The investment would show growing links among major technology companies as they race to build advanced AI systems.

It's led to chip suppliers, cloud providers and model developers deepening financial and strategic ties.

Nvidia declined to comment when contacted by Reuters.

The person said OpenAI is set to use much of the fresh capital to purchase Nvidia's chips.

They power the training and deployment of its AI models.

The Financial Times reported Nvidia's new investment would replace a commitment it announced in September.

It had previously said it would invest up to $100 billion to support OpenAI's use of its chips in data centers.

content.title: Nvidia close to investing $30 billion in OpenAI's funding round: source
content.summary:
STORY: Nvidia is reportedly close to finalizing a $30 billion investment in OpenAI.

As the chipmaker moves to take a stake in one of its largest customers.

That's according to a source speaking to Reuters.

They said the investment is part of a fundraising round in which OpenAI is seeking more than $100 billion.

It would value the ChatGPT maker at about $830 billion and amount to one of the largest private capital raises on record.

Reuters previously reported that SoftBank Group and Amazon are also likely to take part in the round.

The investment would show growing links among major technology companies as they race to build advanced AI systems.

It's led to chip suppliers, cloud providers and model developers deepening financial and strategic ties.

Nvidia declined to comment when contacted by Reuters.

The person said OpenAI is set to use much of the fresh capital to purchase Nvidia's chips.

They power the training and deployment of its AI models.

The Financial Times reported Nvidia's new investment would replace a commitment it announced in September.

It had previously said it would invest up to $100 billion to support OpenAI's use of its chips in data centers.

headline: AI Spending Boom Likely Has Erased This Key Supporting Plank for Stock Performance
summary: The largest U.S. tech companies are on pace to spend about as much money as it cost to build the domestic railroads, around five times the amount needed to create a federal highway system, and 10 times the cash needed to put a man on the moon.  The so-called Big Four hyperscalers—  Microsoft Alphabet Meta Platforms  and  Amazon.com  —are forecast to spend at least $600 billion on artificial-intelligence buildouts in 2026.  Add  Oracle  projected spending and the tally rises to $650 billion, a near 60% increase from 2025 levels.

content.title: AI Spending Boom Likely Has Erased This Key Supporting Plank for Stock Performance
content.summary: The largest U.S. tech companies are on pace to spend about as much money as it cost to build the domestic railroads, around five times the amount needed to create a federal highway system, and 10 times the cash needed to put a man on the moon.  The so-called Big Four hyperscalers—  Microsoft Alphabet Meta Platforms  and  Amazon.com  —are forecast to spend at least $600 billion on artificial-intelligence buildouts in 2026.  Add  Oracle  projected spending and the tally rises to $650 billion, a near 60% increase from 2025 levels.

headline: Amazon's cloud unit hit by outage involving AI tools in December
summary: Amazon's cloud unit AWS had suffered an outage impacting a cost-management feature ‌in December, a spokesperson told Reuters on ‌Friday.  The report said AWS suffered a 13-hour interruption to a ‌system used by ⁠customers when engineers allowed its Kiro AI coding tool to carry out ⁠certain changes.  "That event ‌interrupted an AWS feature - a single service used for cost management - not AWS generally," the Amazon spokesperson said in an emailed statement, adding that the event impacted a system used by customers ‌to monitor usage costs in one ​of its 39 regions.

content.title: Amazon's cloud unit hit by outage involving AI tools in December
content.summary: Amazon's cloud unit AWS had suffered an outage impacting a cost-management feature ‌in December, a spokesperson told Reuters on ‌Friday.  The report said AWS suffered a 13-hour interruption to a ‌system used by ⁠customers when engineers allowed its Kiro AI coding tool to carry out ⁠certain changes.  "That event ‌interrupted an AWS feature - a single service used for cost management - not AWS generally," the Amazon spokesperson said in an emailed statement, adding that the event impacted a system used by customers ‌to monitor usage costs in one ​of its 39 regions.

headline: AI Investment Shines in a Sluggish Economy

headline: Nike, Big Tech, furniture stocks reacting to SCOTUS tariff ruling
summary: Yahoo Finance Markets and Data Editor Jared Blikre and Senior Reporter Brooke DiPalma join Market Domination Host Josh Lipton in tracking several of the day's top trending stock tickers after US Supreme Court officials struck down President Trump's trade tariffs on Friday, including Bob's Discount Furniture (BOBS), Leggett & Platt (LEG), Wayfair (W), RH (RH), Nike (NKE), Amazon (AMZN), Alphabet (GOOG, GOOGL), and Apple (AAPL). To watch more expert insights and analysis on the latest market action, check out more Market Domination.

content.title: Nike, Big Tech, furniture stocks reacting to SCOTUS tariff ruling
content.description:
Yahoo Finance Markets and Data Editor Jared Blikre and Senior Reporter Brooke DiPalma join Market Domination Host Josh Lipton in tracking several of the day's top trending stock tickers after US Supreme Court officials struck down President Trump's trade tariffs on Friday, including Bob's Discount Furniture (BOBS), Leggett & Platt (LEG), Wayfair (W), RH (RH), Nike (NKE), Amazon (AMZN), Alphabet (GOOG, GOOGL), and Apple (AAPL).

To watch more expert insights and analysis on the latest market action, check out more Market Domination.
content.summary: Yahoo Finance Markets and Data Editor Jared Blikre and Senior Reporter Brooke DiPalma join Market Domination Host Josh Lipton in tracking several of the day's top trending stock tickers after US Supreme Court officials struck down President Trump's trade tariffs on Friday, including Bob's Discount Furniture (BOBS), Leggett & Platt (LEG), Wayfair (W), RH (RH), Nike (NKE), Amazon (AMZN), Alphabet (GOOG, GOOGL), and Apple (AAPL). headline: Moody’s shifts Amazon outlook to stable amid AI infrastructure spending
summary: Investing.com -- Moody’s Ratings has revised its outlook for Amazon.com Inc (NASDAQ:AMZN) to stable from positive, signaling a shift in the e-commerce giant’s credit trajectory. The credit agency simultaneously affirmed Amazon’s A1 senior unsecured rating, citing the company's dominant market position and robust brand equity. The revision follows Amazon’s strategic decision to increase capital spending by over 50% to approximately $200 billion to bolster its technology infrastructure. This massi

headline: Tesla to Discontinue Model S, X After 630,000+ Sales
summary: After helping Tesla join the Magnificent 7, the Model S and X will be discontinued as the company shifts focus toward robotics and an autonomous Cybercab.
